awd_titl_txt: Accretion and compaction of chondrule dust rims
awd_abstract_narration:
The present theory of our solar system’s origin involves a massive concentration of dust and gas collapsing under gravity, forming a star that is embedded in a protoplanetary disk of material from which planets, moons, asteroids, and comets form.  Meteorites can provide evidence of how this dust and gas formed rocky objects in this protoplanetary disk.  This laboratory and theoretical research program will address whether fine-grained-dust rims around chrondrules in stony meteorites can cause them to form larger objects, which become the building blocks of asteroids.  Undergraduate students at Baylor University and at the University of Texas at Austin will be trained in modern laboratory techniques.

This research will determine the initial structural properties of dust rims accreted by chondrules. A numerical dust coagulation code with enhancements with to treat ellipsoidal and charged grains will be used to determine the pre-compaction porosity, morphology, and grain alignment of chondrule at the dust grain level. The effect of collisions on fine-grained dust rims (FGRs) compaction will be calculated using the shock physics code iSALE2D modified to represent porous FGRs as a result of collisions between rimmed-chondrule or planetesimals. Numerical simulations of the passage of shock waves through material containing rimmed chondrules will be performed. The morphology, grain alignment, and porosity of FGRs in CO, CR, and CV chondrites will be measured. This experimental work will examine how FGRs form minimally altered carbonaceous chondrites using X-ray computed tomography, electron backscatter diffraction and electron Probe microanalysis. These results will be compared to the structural properties obtained in the models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This research endeavor, conducted in collaboration with undergraduate students from Baylor University and the University of Texas at Austin, explored the formation, evolution and characteristics of fine-grained dust rims around chondrules—tiny spherical grains found in stony meteorites. These fine-grained rims (FGRs) are important meteoritic components because they may have helped asteroid precursors to assemble, acting as a type of "glue" that enabled chondrules to stick together in the solar nebula. 

The research program employed a multi-faceted approach, integrating computer simulations and modern laboratory techniques. For the simulations, we employed a numerical dust coagulation code with enhancements to consider ellipsoidal and electrically charged grains, unraveling the porosity, morphology, and grain alignment of FGRs as they were "freshly" accreted by chondrules.

The project also investigated the role of collisions between rimmed chondrules and fast-moving dust in modifying FGRs. To this end, we employed the shock physics code iSALE2D, specially adapted to represent porous FGRs. The transition from a fluffy to a compact structure in FGRs remains unclear, and our simulations explored the hypothesis that shocks in protoplanetary disks, such as the solar nebula from which the solar system formed, contributed to FGR modification. We modeled collisions between dusty shock fronts (termed "dust clouds") and chondrule surfaces with porous FGRs. Varying impact speed, dust abundance, and initial FGR porosity, we measured changes in dust temperatures, pressures, and net mass accretion. Our findings showed qualitative similarities with petrographic analyses of a specific chondritic meteorite, suggesting that shock-induced processes played a role in shaping meteorite structures.

The main goal for the laboratory portion of this project was an investigation of the possible alignment of the tiny grains in FGRs. Previous work measured an alignment of grains in an FGR, suggesting that these grains were compacted by a nebular process, such as shocks, prior to their accretion into a larger body.  However, our work revealed that in the most primitive, unprocessed meteorites, these grains have completely random orientations. This suggests either a unique accretion history for these most primitive meteorites, or that grain alignment in FGRs results from a non-nebular process (i.e., on the meteorite parent body after accretion).

 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/11/2024
Modified by: Augusto Carballido
